refs.quote: RuPaul doesn't need this much makeup.
refs.description: A spritely young woman sits down with Lorelai. They exchange sisterly banter. Are they sisters? Friends?
refs.refNotes: Although active in other mediums, RuPaul is listed as a "TV" because television brought his name to the masses and was most likely the way Rory would have come to know about him. RuPaul's first national exposure was in 1989 in The B-52's music video "Love Shack".

refs.quote: I'm sorry. I lost my Macy Gray CD and I need caffeine.
refs.description: first time we ever meet Rory. We don't know that she's Lorelai's daughter. They like the same music. It's cute. So we assume they're friends. Later around minute 32, Lorelai and Rory are fighting. When alone, both put on the same Macy Gray CD to sulk.

refs.quote: Look, officer Krupke. She's right at that table, right over there.
refs.description: Luke thinks Lorelai is trying to get more coffee for herself by saying it's for Rory. She mocks him, likening him to the the police officer character in West Side Story.
refs.refIs: is a fictional character from West Side Story.

refs.quote: For those of you who have not finished the final chapters of Huckleberry Finn you may use this time to do so.
refs.description: Girls around Rory try finger nail polish while she ignores them and writes her assignment. They are astonished at her nerdiness. Psht.

refs.quote: Oh, well, there's no way Mark Twain can compete with that.
refs.description: Refers to prior scene in school. Mark Twain is being compared to glittery nail polish that smells like bubblegum when it dries. Naturally.

refs.quote: I'm gonna be in a Britney Spears video?
refs.description: Upon receiving a plaid skirt as a gift from her mother. Shortly thereafter she finds out she will be attending a private school called Chilton. Hooray!
refs.refNotes: First album ("...Baby One More Time")released in 1999.

refs.quote: Sookie, there are several chapters from a Stephen King novel I'd reenact before I'd resort to that option.
refs.description: Lorelie is trying to figure out how to afford the enrollment fee for Chilton. Sookie suggests she call her parents for help. This is the first we've heard of them.
refs.refNotes: Born in 1947, first novel ("Carrie") released in 1973..

refs.quote: It's at Zsa Zsa Gabor's house.
refs.description: A lightning quick reply to Sookie's question from the kitchen "Where's your pate?"

refs.quote: God! You're just like Ruth Gordon just standing there with a tannis root.
refs.description: Rory spills her books and (gasp) meets her first crush. As luck would have it (gasp) he gets the reference to Rosemary's Baby.
refs.refIs: is a ((fictional))? <!> character in the film "Rosemary's Baby".

refs.quote: Rosemary's Baby.
refs.description: A handsome young buck surprises Rory by catching her reference to a 60s horror film - and then throwing back a compliment. Le gasp.

refs.quote: Chicago. Windy. Oprah.
refs.description: Rory's flirting skills at their maximum. The Oprah was filmed in Chicago.
refs.refIs: is a popular talk show host.

refs.quote: So, how are you liking Moby Dick?
refs.description: Dear Dean has just subtly let Rory know that he has paid attention to her reading habits. Smooth.
refs.refIs: is a classic novel by Herman Melville.

refs.quote: It's my first Melville.
refs.description: You never forget your first love, erm...Melville. Rory gives us a glimpse at how much of a book worm she really is.
refs.refIs: was a novelist, famous for writing "Moby Dick."

refs.quote: Last week it was Madame Bovary.
refs.description: Dean reveals he's been watching Rory. Of course, not in a "...creepy, like 'I'm watching you' sort of way," but because she's "nice to look at," and has "unbelievable concentration."

refs.quote: You're gonna have to turn into Flo-Jo to get away from me.
refs.description: Remember when earlier in the episode Rory said she sucked at sports? Heh heh.
refs.refIs: was an American Olympic track star.
refs.refNotes: "Flo Jo" was a nickname for Florence Griffith Joyner during the <!> Summer Olympic Games.

refs.quote: You're not going to give me the 'Mommy Dearest' treatment forever, are ya?
refs.description: Lorelai wants to know when she will no longer be the villain in Rory's version of the present. Then again, she did just try to trick Rory back into being friends by offering her a few hours of work at the Inn "for extra cash." Nice try, mom.
refs.refIs: was an biographic film about Joan Crawford.
refs.refNotes: In "Mommy Dearest," the lead character (based on the real-life actress Joan Crawford) is an abusive mother.

refs.quote: So do we go in or do we just stand here reenacting The Little Match Girl?
refs.description: Lorelai is having trouble knocking on the door for the dreaded off-holiday dinner with her parental unit.
refs.refNotes: In the story "The Little Match Girl," a scared little girl avoids going home because she is afraid of her father. Video link is to film adaptation <!>.

refs.quote: Okay, look, I know you and me are having a thing here and I know you hate me but I need you to be civil - at least through dinner â€“ and then on the way home you can pull a Menendez.
refs.description: Lorelai asks for a truce in exchange for the opportunity for Rory to murder her later. Ah, parenting.
refs.refIs: were siblings convicted of killing their parents.

refs.quote: We're thinking of having her studied at M.I.T.
refs.description: Because she's tall. She's 5'7. That's tall. Lorelai, you're daughter's tall. A few minutes later in the episode, as the two are leaving, Lorelai asks Rory "Do I look shorter, because I feel shorter." A classic GG writer move.
refs.refIs: a university well-known for its scientific research.

refs.quote: That's so Nick at Night.
refs.description: Mom wants to know about the boy. Mom wants to know if he's "dreamy."
refs.refIs: <!>(( is/was )) a television program that features (( d )) old TV shows such as "I Love Lucy."
